title: Classic Brioche
description: A rich, buttery French bread that teaches you about enriched doughs. With eggs and butter making up a large portion of the dough, brioche pushes gluten development to its limits.

steps.instruction: In a stand mixer bowl (or large bowl), combine flour, sugar, salt, and yeast. Add the eggs and mix on low speed with the dough hook until a shaggy dough forms. Increase to medium speed and knead for about 10 minutes until the dough is smooth and elastic.
tips: Brioche dough is very sticky — resist adding extra flour. The stickiness is from the eggs.
The dough should pull cleanly from the sides of the bowl when ready.
If kneading by hand, use the 'slap and fold' technique on a clean surface.

steps.instruction: With the mixer on medium-low, add the cold butter one cube at a time, waiting for each piece to be mostly incorporated before adding the next. This will take about 10 minutes. The dough will look broken and messy midway — this is normal. Keep mixing until smooth.
tips: Cold butter is key — it incorporates into the gluten network without melting and making the dough greasy.
At 50% butter (baker's percentage), this is a heavily enriched dough. The fat coats gluten strands, making the final bread incredibly tender.
Don't panic when the dough falls apart mid-mixing. It will come back together.

steps.instruction: Once all butter is incorporated, continue mixing on medium speed until the dough is smooth, shiny, and elastic. It should pass the windowpane test — you can stretch a piece thin enough to see light through it without tearing.
tips: The dough should slap the sides of the bowl cleanly.
It will feel very soft and slightly sticky, but not wet.
The windowpane should be even and smooth — this is fully developed gluten.

steps.instruction: Transfer the dough to a lightly oiled bowl, cover tightly with plastic wrap, and let it rise at room temperature for 1 hour.
tips: It won't double — enriched doughs rise slower because the fat and sugar weigh them down.
You're looking for about 50% increase in volume.
This initial rise develops flavor before the long cold fermentation.

steps.instruction: Punch down the dough, wrap tightly in plastic, and refrigerate overnight (at least 8 hours, up to 24). Cold fermentation firms the butter, makes the dough easier to shape, and develops deep flavor.
tips: This overnight rest is not optional — cold dough is essential for shaping brioche.
The slow, cold fermentation produces complex flavors that quick rises can't match.
The butter solidifies in the fridge, giving the dough structure.

steps.instruction: Remove the dough from the fridge. For a loaf: divide into 4 equal pieces, shape each into a smooth ball, and place side by side in a greased 9x5 inch loaf pan. For rolls: divide into 8 pieces and place in a muffin tin or on a baking sheet.
tips: Work quickly — the dough is easiest to shape while still cold.
Tuck the dough under itself to create surface tension on top.
If it gets too warm and sticky, return to the fridge for 15 minutes.

steps.instruction: Cover and let the shaped brioche proof at room temperature until nearly doubled and the dough looks puffy and jiggly when you gently shake the pan.
tips: This takes 1.5–2 hours because the dough is cold from the fridge.
Preheat your oven to 175°C (350°F) toward the end of proofing.
The dough should jiggle like jelly when the pan is tapped.

steps.instruction: Gently brush the top with egg wash (1 beaten egg + 1 tablespoon water). Bake at 175°C (350°F) until deep golden brown and the internal temperature reaches 88°C (190°F).
tips: The egg wash gives brioche its signature glossy, dark golden crust.
If the top browns too quickly, tent loosely with foil.
Let it cool in the pan for 10 minutes, then turn out onto a wire rack.
The crumb will be incredibly soft, rich, and slightly yellow from the eggs.
